A Haunting Blend of Fantasy and Truth This film offers a clever and striking fusion of fantasy and realism, using its surreal narrative as a mirror to reflect the unsettling truths of our modern world. Beneath the surface of its mythical elements lies a poignant critique of a deeply flawed healthcare system—one that thrives on exploitation, favouring profit over people. It's a story that exposes how wealth, while seductive, can become a curse in disguise—slowly suffocating the soul it was meant to liberate. Thought-provoking and eerie, it lingers long after the credits roll.

Death of a Unicorn delivers a bold mix of black comedy and satirical horror, exposing the brutal greed of capitalism in a wild, bloody ride. The story is simple yet direct, filled with absurd humor and surprisingly tender moments between the leads. While the wealthy villains feel cartoonish and the film only scratches the surface of its deeper themes, it remains an energetic, heartfelt, and visually vibrant experience. Alex Scharfman shows promise in his directorial debut, using saturated colors, dynamic camera work, and playful editing to keep the tone lively, though pacing stumbles midway. Performances shine, especially from Paul Rudd’s charmingly naïve father and Jenna Ortega’s sharp, sarcastic daughter. Despite its flaws, Death of a Unicorn offers a rebellious and fun cinematic escape — perfect for fans of quirky, blood-soaked dark comedies.

Death of a Unicorn sets out to answer a question no one’s really thought to ask: What would happen if unicorns existed—and were also kinda evil? The answer: Chaos. Before I go any further...Spoiler warning: This written review contains spoilers. If you're spoiler-averse, check out the two-minute spoiler-free version on my TikTok (@uninvited.reviewe) and Instagram (@uninvited_reviewer). My unsolicited opinion: Screen it (if you can handle a lot of gore) Let’s run through the good, the bad, and the horrifying. We start on a plane with Elliot (Paul Rudd), a recently widowed father, and his college-aged daughter Ridley (Jenna Ortega), heading off on a vague work trip. We don’t get much backstory other than the fact that the mother/wife recently died, and the father-daughter relationship is... strained. It’s the classic “dad tries too hard to win his daughter’s love when all she wants is to be heard” trope we’ve seen a million times. Honestly, it’s kind of wild that this cliché plays in the background of this movie. Personally, I think keeping the mom alive might have created a more compelling contrast between functional and dysfunctional family dynamics. On the way to a work meeting, Elliot hits a unicorn with his car. You did read that right, and if it surprised you, might I point you back in the direction of the title of the movie? Don't worry though, just when you think things are about to get too predictable, Paul Rudd comes out of nowhere and goes at the not-quite-dead-yet unicorn with a tire iron until, well, you learn that unicorn blood is purple. Fun! They toss the body into the trunk of their rental car and head off to their destination, planning to bury it later. Leaving me to wonder if purple blood would be harder to get out of upholstery than red blood. And if they thought to get rental insurance..... Anyway. Their destination: a mega-mansion owned by the ultra-rich Leopold family, who made their fortune in pharmaceuticals (shocking, I know). We meet Melinda (Téa Leoni), her husband Odell (Richard E. Grant), and their son Shepard (Will Poulter), who greets the guests with the line:"Come here for a cut of the good stuff." (Delivered in such a sincerely deadpan way that I laughed out loud.) The Leopold family is perfectly cast—especially Leoni and Poulter. I want a whole prequel just about them; there are so many hints at an unsettling past that’s just as disturbing as the present events. Odell is dying of cancer, and Elliot is there in hopes of becoming the family’s estate lawyer—a very lucrative gig. But once everyone’s at the mansion, the real chaos kicks in. Unicorn blood, it turns out, has healing properties. And once the Leopolds discover this, their home turns into a mad-scientist lab overnight. The catch? The unicorn isn’t actually dead. It keeps coming back. One standout scene has the entire cast circling the newly re-dead unicorn, refusing to acknowledge what they’re seeing. Téa Leoni delivers a killer line:"It's definitely some kind of horse-like mammalia." Another laugh-out-loud moment. The baffled reactions across the board make this scene one of the movie’s best. But this is a horror-comedy, so things must get serious eventually—and boy, do they. In under two hours (108 minutes), the movie wrings out every bit of its premise. When crushed unicorn horn cures Odell’s cancer—and can’t be reproduced in a lab—Odell gleefully announces:"Supply is scarce, so demand will be high." Thus begins a bidding war among the 1%. Leading Melinda to declare, "I haven’t had this much fun since we launched FenFen in ’94!"—a line so darkly hilarious I laughed and immediately felt guilty. That scene is a perfect storm of horror, satire, and discomfort. The film swings big, but its sharpest moments lie in the smaller details— the reactions, and the dead panned one liners that land like punches. In one such moment, the core theme becomes clear: Who are the real monsters here? Unfortunately, from this point on, Paul Rudd's Elliot seems to drift aimlessly, and cluelessly, through the story. Once Ridley is positioned as the voice of reason, the film doesn’t quite know what to do with him. Ridley, meanwhile, forges a mysterious bond with the not-quite-dead unicorn. She slips away to investigate—and uncovers a larger threat. But in true horror fashion, no one listens. Enter: two very angry adult unicorns out for blood.The gore is immediate and intense. A wave of gruesome attacks wipes out half the supporting cast in some—memorable ways. The Leopold family responds by... sitting down to dinner.The kicker? Their loyal-ish servant Griff (played to perfection by Anthony Carrigan) brings Odell a unicorn steak. Odell digs in while delivering a monologue that is so full of rich white male privilege Richard E. Grant deserves some kind award for being so self-aware. Because there is no chance he could have delivered such a cutting, unknowingly vitriolic, and morally wrong monologue without having the knowledge of exactly what he was saying as an actor. After a botched hunting party, Odell gets gored in the neck. Chaos erupts. The lights go out. The unicorns invade. Griff flees. In perhaps the most absurd twist, we learn Shepard has been snorting crushed unicorn horn, which supposedly makes him smarter...? The movie doesn’t linger long enough to clarify. More death follows, including the gruesome disemboweling of Melinda—right in front of Shepard. Elliot locks Ridley in a room for “her safety,” underestimating the power of a woman who’s been ignored and proven right. Rookie mistake. The finale wraps up in a somewhat predictable way, but not before we get one great monologue from Jenna Ortega. The police arrive and arrest both Elliot and Ridley. (That’s not quite the end, but I won’t spoil everything—this review is long enough.) Final Verdict Death of a Unicorn isn’t perfect. Its big premise occasionally trips over itself. But it’s a horrifyingly funny takedown of Big Pharma, the ultra-wealthy, and the nature of villainy. The writing is mostly whip-smart and sharp. Its best moments are subtle—so don't scroll while you stream. The acting is solid throughout, especially from the Leopolds and supporting cast. Paul Rudd feels underused while Jenna Ortega deserved more room to lead. If you're a fan of Ready or Not, The Hunt, or Happy Death Day, this one’s for you. unwantedmoviereviews.com

**Review – *Death of a Unicorn* (2.5 stars)** I went into *Death of a Unicorn* with high hopes—mainly because Paul Rudd and Will Poulter are in it, and those two can usually charm the socks off me. And while they do their thing here (Poulter especially, always good for a laugh), the film itself just doesn’t quite hit the mark. It’s got a stacked cast, no doubt, but it starts to feel like window dressing when the story’s this predictable. The unicorn? Surprisingly realistic in some scenes, but occasionally screamed CGI. Budget issues? Rushed post? Who knows—but it’s *about time* we got a proper unicorn flick, even if this one limps more than gallops. The satirical jabs at Big Pharma land here and there, and Anthony Carrigan is a treat as always. But horror? Eh. A few decent kills and jump scares, but it never fully commits to the genre. There’s a better movie buried in here somewhere. Now, on to Jenna Ortega. I’m officially tired. She’s talented, sure, but seeing her *again* as a moody teen? I'm over it. *Death of a Unicorn* has moments of magic, but they’re fleeting. Entertaining in bursts, forgettable in full. At least Rudd still looks like he drinks from a fountain of youth.

The film's narrative revolves around themes of grief, love, and the quest for meaning, making it both relatable and thought-provoking. Not to mention human nature at its core to make a profit off of loss. The storytelling is masterfully crafted, with a script that balances moments of levity and heartache. The characters are well developed, each contributing to the overarching theme of finding hope amidst loss. Visually, the film is a feast for the eyes. The cinematography is stunning, with vibrant colors and breathtaking landscapes that enhance the magical atmosphere of the story. The scenes featuring the mythical unicorn are particularly enchanting, filled with ethereal lighting that captures the essence of wonder. These moments serve as a powerful metaphor for hope and renewal, in my opinion. The supporting cast delivers exceptional performances, bringing depth and authenticity to their roles. Their interactions are filled with humor, providing a perfect counterbalance to the film's more poignant moments. The relationships among the characters are intricately woven, showcasing the importance of connection and community during challenging times. Great casting! "The Death of a Unicorn" is a beautifully crafted film that resonates deeply with me. I love a good developed story, so this was spot on for me. This film is a must-see for anyone looking for a magical and moving cinematic experience that lingers in the heart long after the credits roll.

This was surely the least entertaining film I've seen for very long time - and this is a film that contains unicorns eating people! Yet somehow it takes itself seriously, while at other times playing for the broadest pantomime non-laughs. Richard E Grant should be ashamed of himself - his is probably the broadest and lamest of a lot of very obvious acting performances. All the scares and plot 'twists' are telegraphed - so there are no surprises and little tension. The CGI has a special place in all this - cranky, sped up and unconvincing, it nevertheless still looks like money was wasted on it - I could just imagine some CGI unit chucking this together in their downtime to pay the bills for proper work. There is some tedious 'plot' about a dead mother which fails to land; some suedo-religious stuff and some my little pony cutsie moments. If this is all making it sound fun - it's not. The best moment was probably when a scene went from night-time to daytime with no explanation - so at least you felt they were saving some money on this pile. A bit more incompetence and it could have started to at least be interestingly awful. There is a leaden 'rich people are bad' message - all played with the most obvious and dull caricatures. The Ortega character has a gamin sulky look and some acne - so we know she is going to the spiritual savior. Even her acne disappears in the most laughable plot twist. If this had had a skerrick of tension or one line of funny dialogue I would have given it a star and a half. Alas no - don't waste your money.

The 'rich people are evil' trope falls a bit flat in this "fantasy-horror Knives Out," but the performances of Rudd & Ortega save it. I wish the wealthy folks had more depth - or that the film was more heightened. The realistic film setting with the cartoonishly selfish rich folks didn't blend well for me. The unicorns are genuinely intimidating and the premise is interesting. One thing to note: for some reason, all of the male deaths are quick and to the point, while the female deaths seem to go on for longer and are much more gruesome. It was definitely noticeable.

A gory, good time, "Death of a Unicorn" doesn't take itself too seriously, and as a result, is able to bring us along for a fantastical, sometimes silly, but ultimately good time. Nestled in the untouched Canadian wilderness, a family of CGI unicorns wreak havoc on a a bunch of stuck of rich people looking to exploit nature for their own monetary gains. The only real downside to the movie was having to muster up the suspension of disbelief required to overlook the very clearly computer generated unicorns. Maybe it was intentional as a means to make everything just a bit sillier? Regardless, "Death of a Unicorn" is worth the watch.

Death of a Unicorn is a very uneven, sometimes entertaining film that has many strands but doesn't manage to pull them all together. It's part satire and part horror fantasy, but neither done to the full extent. Elliot and his teenage daughter Ridley are driving to the wildlife estate of his boss, Odell Leopold. Elliot is his lawyer and he is going there so Odell can finalise some documents as he is dying from cancer. As they approach, their car hits a unicorn. Yes, that is right, a unicorn. The film only gets crazier from there. They stuff the unicorn into the boot thinking he is dead. But soon they realise he isn't and that the unicorn has some unique healing powers. This manages to get the Leopold family to try and make the unicorn their own so that they can cash in on its amazing powers. This sloppy film tries to be a satire but it doesn't quite work. It is generally a lot of fun though, even if a little silly and gory at times. A talented cast does fine work, with Will Poulter hilarious as Odell's vain son. A film of promise but a bit of a letdown.

When you think about unicorns, as one does, they’re these white, possibly fluffy, majestic creatures that give us a feeling that everything will be okay. The new A24 movie DEATH OF A UNICORN takes that and twists it into a fun, over-the-top but clever satire. Elliot (Paul Rudd) is a widowed father of Ridley (Jenna Ortega). They drive down to Elliot’s boss’ house Odell, who is dying and needs a proxy to run his company after he’s gone. Other characters include Odell’s wife Belinda (Téa Leoni), their spoiled son Shephard (Will Poulter), and their butler Griff (Anthony Carrigan). On the drive up, Elliot and Ridley hit what looks like a small horse with a girthsome protrusion coming out of its head. Disturbed, they put it in the trunk and carry on. When the others find out, well, they “horse around and find out”. I really enjoyed most of this movie. The amazing cast ensemble knows what kind of movie this is, and has fun with it, especially Poulter and Carrigan. I guess you can think of this as a more humorous JURASSIC PARK. Greedy narcissistic people playing around with something they don’t understand, you know the deal. It gets more violent as the movie goes on. I enjoyed the great but unlikeable characters, each having their moments to shine. The moments of CGI weren’t the greatest, but on a budget of only $15 million, I can’t blame them. My only problem with this movie is how they end up showing us a few different paths the story could go, but it doesn’t really go down any of them. They’re all good ideas, but it would’ve been better if it stuck to one and delved deeper. Other than that, the humor is funny and the violence is violent. Whether DEATH OF A UNICORN works for you or not, original movies are always a welcome and refreshing sight.

Imagine Jurassic Park with unicorns: that is Death of a Unicorn! It’ll work for some and come off as extremely campy for others, but I had such a fun time with it! It really is a satirical Jurassic Park if A24 got weird with it. Instead of dinosaurs, there’s a magical unicorn, a lot of greed, and pure chaos. It takes the “eat the rich” theme to wild, fantastical extremes in Alex Scharfman’s hilarious feature directorial debut. The film is totally camp, and the entire cast plays into the ridiculousness of the story. Sharp in humour, class commentary, and unicorn horn kills, this movie shouldn’t work — but it somehow does. It tackles a familiar concept but injects a fair amount of originality throughout. This cast is an absolute blast to watch interact on-screen, but it is Will Poulter and Anthony Carrigan who steal the show, thanks to Poulter’s insanely funny line reads and Carrigan’s brilliant non-verbal reactions. Jenna Ortega and Paul Rudd commit to the absurdity, carrying this fun, self-aware, well-crafted B-movie. It’s a mix of horror, comedy, and sci-fi satire that mostly hits the mark. It does lose steam as it can’t quite figure out how to bring it all together, but there is plenty of fun to be had. Also, the idea of unicorns turning evil is pretty awesome! It’s an over-the-top, ridiculous B-movie horror-comedy that ended up being a bloody good time and got a few genuine laughs out of me! Sure, it doesn’t have the most original plot structure and ends up being fairly predictable with some lacklustre visual effects, but it's an A24 killer unicorn movie that is pretty funny… what more could you want?!

Death of a Unicorn is a wild, genre-blending ride that takes you places you absolutely weren’t expecting—but you’ll be glad you went. Imagine Jurassic Park, E.T., Taken, and Aliens all thrown into a blender and cranked to high speed—that’s the energy this film delivers from start to finish. Jenna Ortega continues to prove she’s one of the most magnetic young actors working today. She brings sharp wit, vulnerability, and a grounded presence that anchors the madness around her. Will Poulter is a perfect complement—equal parts awkward charm and unflinching intensity. Their dynamic gives the film its emotional pulse amid all the chaos. The plot is absurd in the best way, the visuals are stunningly weird, and the tone swings from heartfelt to hilarious to horrifying without missing a beat. It’s not perfect—some of the pacing stumbles and the genre mash-up might not be for everyone—but it’s bold, original, and never boring. If you’re in the mood for something totally off the rails but anchored by two killer performances, Death of a Unicorn is a must-watch.

A Sprinkle of Magic, But Ultimately Mundane. A24's Death of a Unicorn arrives with a quirky premise and the studio's signature promise of something a little off-kilter. The setup – a father and daughter accidentally hitting a unicorn, leading to corporate exploitation and mythical mayhem – certainly teases a good time. However, while the film offers moments of dark humor and an intriguing concept, it ultimately feels like a missed opportunity, a fantastical dish that's missing a key ingredient. The cast, featuring Paul Rudd and the captivating Jenna Ortega, do their best with the material. Will Poulter steals the movie as he typically does. There are glimpses of the sharp satire A24 is known for, particularly in its skewering of pharmaceutical greed and the absurd lengths the wealthy will go to for profit. Richard E. Grant, as the villainous CEO, chews the scenery with relish, embodying the avarice at the film's core. Yet, despite these promising elements, Death of a Unicorn struggles to fully coalesce. The humor can be uneven, landing with a thud as often as it elicits a chuckle. The horror elements, while present, feel somewhat muted, never quite reaching the level of tension or dread one might expect from the premise. The film seems unsure whether to lean fully into its comedic absurdity or its darker, more satirical undertones, resulting in a tonal imbalance that prevents it from truly excelling in either genre. Ultimately, Death of a Unicorn feels like one of those films that has a great elevator pitch but falters in its execution. It offers enough intriguing ideas and entertaining performances to hold your attention, but it doesn't quite deliver the satisfying or memorable experience you might hope for from an A24 production. While it's not a bad film, it doesn't fully capitalize on its potential. You'll likely have a decent enough time, but it's the kind of movie that will probably feel more rewarding to watch from the comfort of your couch when it eventually hits streaming platforms, saving you the price of a theatrical ticket for an experience that ultimately feels a little underwhelming.

Death of a Unicorn – Sparkles, Scream-Snorts, and Straight-Up Chaos Well. That was unhinged. Death of a Unicorn is like if Jurassic Park and Lisa Frank had a deeply confusing love child after drinking expired kombucha. And I say that with affection. I enjoyed this movie more than I probably should have. It was wild, weird, and somehow made unicorn blood seem like the most logical cure-all for my back pain, seasonal allergies, and general life fatigue. Let’s just get this out of the way: yes, the unicorns growled and I swear one of them had the exact same snort-roar as the T. rex from Jurassic Park. There were shots, lighting, and musical swells that made me look around the theater like, “Wait—is anyone else hearing this? Are we in Isla Nublar or Narnia?” The only thing missing was Jeff Goldblum in a leather vest whispering, “Life finds a way… through glitter.” Paul Rudd was solid, but let’s be honest—we all wanted peak Paul. Full quirky, snarky, sarcastic Paul. Instead, we got Paul on a decaf latte. Still charming, but I missed the signature sparkle. Give me that man riffing with a unicorn, please. The storyline itself? Surprisingly deep. Cheesy, sure—but also weirdly reflective in a “wait, am I crying over a mythical horse’s existential crisis?” kind of way. It somehow balanced heartfelt moments with scenes that felt like they were written during a sugar crash. The humor worked for me—definitely campy, but it leaned into the madness and owned it. The only real gripe? The baby unicorn. That poor thing looked like it wandered in from a low-budget fantasy game on Steam. The adult unicorns had this majestic, believable look—like they belonged in a slightly terrifying enchanted forest. The baby? Looked like someone duct-taped a horn to a goat plushie and hoped for the best. Still, I can’t say I was bored for even a second. It had blood. It had sparkle. It had moral dilemmas. It had… unicorns running in slow motion while roaring like prehistoric nightmares. Final thoughts? It was absolutely bonkers—and I was absolutely here for it. Would I watch it again? Probably. Would I drink unicorn blood for chronic fatigue? Don’t tempt me.

Unicorns and Slashers? Yes, Please. But This One Tried Too Hard and Delivered Too Little. I was genuinely excited for this movie—the idea of a mythical slasher-comedy featuring unicorns sounded like chaotic fun in the best way. It had all the right elements: a wildly original concept, a great cast, solid effects, and a tone that could’ve been something special. But sadly, it didn’t come together the way I hoped. The comedy didn’t land for me, and the pacing was way off—it felt about 40 minutes too long. I actually considered leaving, but my husband was determined to see it through. The gore was a lot. I’m an ’80s girl, so I’m not squeamish, but this went beyond creative kills into just plain over-the-top. I found myself covering my eyes more than I expected to for a movie that was supposed to be a comedy. As much as I love Paul Rudd, his “dumb dad” character felt out of place, and the family’s weird level of control over everything made the plot feel more confusing than clever. I wanted to love this movie. I really did. But for all its potential, it just tried too hard and ended up feeling like a missed opportunity.

"Death of a Unicorn" is more concerned with being fun and entertaining than other A24 films can feel. The movie has scary moments and a dark sense of humor, but I feel had me engaged the whole way through even with the many tones. I think the premise is simple enough and I think the story was executed in a solid way. I did feel the lore of unicorns felt a bit lacking and that aspect of it could have been more interesting. I also think the movie played it pretty safe and could have gone in even wackier directions if it wanted to. The ending of the movie also feels a bit abrupt for me and I don't think the movie has as much closure as I would have preferred. Nonetheless, I think the actors are really carrying this one a level above an okay movie and I also appreciated seeing something that felt original. Overall, it is a movie that has seemed to be divisive, but I personally liked it and appreciated many qualities about it, and still feel hopeful of what is to come from A24 in 2025.

Honestly, this movie—and the reviews surrounding it—really highlight how out of touch modern film criticism has become. It feels like so many critics today are just bitter film school grads tossing around buzzwords they picked up in screenwriting 101. There’s a complete disconnect between what’s genuinely entertaining and what they think makes a “good” movie. This was a fun film. Pure camp. Tongue-in-cheek and totally self-aware, with genuine laugh-out-loud moments throughout. I saw it in a theater with maybe 30 people, and the room was constantly cracking up. It’s absurd, it’s silly, it knows exactly what it is—and it leans in hard. The performances were great across the board. Anthony Carrigan is a standout (as always), and Téa Leoni was a surprising comedic highlight. The whole cast had sharp, clever delivery that kept things moving and fresh. Sure, it’s not perfect. It stumbles a bit in the third act and probably runs 10 minutes too long (a problem plaguing way too many movies lately). But honestly? I didn’t care. I had a great time. And enjoyed it the entire time. You will too. Go see this. Support this kind of film. Give a big middle finger to critics who clearly don’t know how to evaluate comedy anymore—and definitely not how to champion movies that are actually fun.

Brilliant! Lots of fun to watch! This is one of those movies where you can see how removed from normal the "professional" movie critics are. The ratings from the bulk of the "top critics" on RT is pretty bad but from normal people the movie is scoring pretty high and for good reason: it's a great movie to watch! This is another one of those films you really need to see in the theater because the scale of the screen and quality of the picture and sound is so vastly superior than any big screen tv, not to mention that the size of the actual picture has a far greater impact on the viewer precisely because it is so very large. It cannot be replicated at home. Having said that, Jenna Ortega is awesome as always and Paul Rudd does his Dad thing very well. Richard Grant does an outstanding job playing the narcissistic billionaire on his last legs and then suddenly reborn as a result of the unicorn and Tea Leoni plays the billionaire's socialite wife to perfection. All the other actors including the supporting staff comprised mainly of servants at the billionaire's remote "lodge" did an excellent job too. I see a number of sourpusses complaining about the CGI and I think that's nonsense. These are unicorns after all, so if you expect to be convinced that they are real I feel sorry for ya. I suppose the unicorns could have been rendered somehow more accurately but to obsess about that point it to miss the point. This is a real fairy tale come to life on the screen. People forget that most children's fables and fairy tales are intentionally scary and often do not end well and therein lies the lesson for the young hearts and minds to learn. That's what happens in this picture. It's a lighthearted horror flick that does it's job very well in a magnificent setting and with a magnificent set. The "creatures" are as believable as anything can or should be in a movie about unicorns and frankly, I thought they were done pretty damn well TBH. My one quibble would be with the sounds they make. They roar in the same way a T Rex would in the Jurassic Park movies. Since there's nothing to go on it works well enough but I would have thought one of the sound geniuses in Hollywood might have come up with some sort of ferocious whinnying or something more horse like. But that's unimportant. What counts is that the story, the script, the cinematography and the cast were all top notch and the movie itself is entertaining, a bit funny and has some horror too. With such A-list actors, the movie was poorly directed and acted, as the relationships were very unbelievable and boring. The creature effects were muppet-like and unpolished, and the storyline was disjointed and not believable. It was like they took inspiration from ‘Jurassic Patk’, ‘Knives Out’, ‘We Bought a Zoo’ and ‘Harry Potter’, while attempting to throw in some politics, Big Pharm and conservation views, and blend it all together into a disaster. You know what you're gonna get when you sit down to watch it. Dumb fun about unicorns on a murderous rampage. Loved the movie !! It is a fantastic creature flick.

What would happen if you accidentally killed a unicorn and discovered it had magical healing powers? There’s a message here, but it doesn’t land as effectively as it should. The film tries to criticize big pharma and the financial interests of medical corporations, but that theme gets lost among a father/daughter story, horror elements, and various other distractions. The script ends up feeling pretty muddled. Why are these magical unicorns even alive? And why is Jenna Ortega involved? Why is unicorn meat being eaten? (There’s a lot to unpack.) And all of this unfolds over the span of just one weekend. Just one weekend, and so much happens in such a short time. Jenna Ortega and Will Poulter both gave strong performances. Poulter was particularly funny and had some memorable moments. Paul Rudd, on the other hand, was a bit typecast as the goofy dad and lawyer who can’t seem to get anything right—he was just okay. However, Téa Leoni really stood out. She did an amazing job, and it's been a while since we've seen her on screen. Her portrayal of the entitled yet "caring" rich philanthropist mom was spot on. I’ve met people like the characters in this family, and they all did an excellent job bringing them to life in this movie.
Kinda predictable story but definitely a fun movie. Rudd and Ortega make a great onscreen pair and Poulter steals every scene he’s in. Definitely worth watching in theaters!

Death of A Unicorn is more than just a fantasy - its theme shows man's involvement with greed, and the so-called "fountain of youth," while making us understand the true meaning of humanity's need for compassion and holding on to the hope of existence. Although a bit corny, and also stereotypical in characterizations, I did feel a warm glow (like the unicorn's horn) when I viewed this film. I had a hard day and this seemed to make me smile. Another era of an ET type of film, it is a smile..
Wild and trippy as heck. If you want to enjoy going out of your mind in a fun way, I’d watch this.

Good acting by the whole cast, but the film is just not good. The story is all over the place and lacks a clear direction, is it a comedy horror or a semi serious comment on modern society and privilege. It’s probably worth a watch just for the great performances of Jenna Ortega and Paul Rudd.

I love the actors/actresses and I think the script for this movie was more natural and good writing. I liked the ending the most and how it met a deeper meaning but I do wish it started with that more so to feel at a deeper level for the daughter and father by the end. I thought it was done well tho and worth watching. ((: it was decently made. Not every movie has to be amazing and perfect y’all. I think people hating on this movie either just can’t do multiple genres or they just want to hate lol All movies are different.

This may not have been an oscar or an academy award contender, but it sure will get you through a nice chill outing. The cast was simply great and they did deliver their share. It has its cheesy predictable plot and dialogue but nonetheless it makes you want to see what will happen. For this fantasy film, just sit back, clear your mind and enjoy whats playing on screen.

Death of a Unicorn offers a fun, fresh, and almost nostalgic vibe, reminiscent of stumbling upon a cheesy creature feature on the Syfy Channel in the early 2000s. While the film has its fair share of flaws, the joyride it provides makes it easy to overlook them. Let’s start with the cast. None of the actors deliver performances that will have you scrambling for award nominations. By now, we know what to expect from a Jenna Ortega-led film, and here she fits that mold. Paul Rudd, who is always a delight, seems to have dialed it back a bit, offering a more subdued performance than usual. Still, the true standout moments come from Will Poulter and Anthony Carrigan, whose lines are some of the most quotable in the film. That said, while the acting isn’t remarkable, it’s not inherently bad either. The cast is likable enough to carry the film’s charm, even if they don’t fully elevate the material. The film’s biggest issue, however, is pacing. Despite a solid runtime of 1 hour and 44 minutes, Death of a Unicorn feels like a much longer experience. Yet, surprisingly, I never found myself bored. The slow pacing is counterbalanced by the movie’s quirks: the atrocious CGI unicorns, the occasionally underwhelming performances from capable actors, and the overall oddball tone. Ultimately, what really makes Death of a Unicorn one of my favorite movies of the year so far is its fantastic writing. The script brings a surprising depth to its world, making the flaws easy to forgive and turning what could’ve been a forgettable creature feature into something oddly endearing.

There’s this thing that happens when you’re a teacher, or a mentor, or just someone who really gives a care about potential. You watch someone you know is brilliant deliver something that’s good—really good, even—but not their best. And you’re left in this liminal place, where admiration knots with disappointment. That’s where Death of a Unicorn left me. This is A24’s latest offering, and like most of their catalog, it begins with promise. No, not promise—magic. The opening hits hard: the pacing is kinetic, conversations feel sharp and alive, and the stakes don’t rise so much as escalate in this orchestrated dance of absurdism and sincerity. It’s like someone spliced the DNA of Swiss Army Man with a dash of Paddington gone pagan, and somehow it worked. But then. The spell weakens. Somewhere past the midpoint, it begins to cave in on itself. What once felt daringly surreal turns familiar. The absurd loses its teeth, and suddenly you see the strings—the mechanics of plot, the too-obvious MacGuffin (the unicorn horn, of course), wrapped in mystery just long enough for you to think, Please don’t do the thing I think you’re gonna do. And then they do. Exactly that. The switcheroo. The inevitable handoff. A trope dressed in glitter and hoofprints. What frustrates me the most isn’t the failure—it’s the unrealized potential. There are ideas here—rich, weird, textured ideas—that never get their due. Like the character who huffs unicorn powder and his eyes glow like he's unlocked some arcane cheat code. That could’ve been something! Give me some body horror, give me unicorn-mutation, give me healing-factor-Wolverine-type vibes. Let him sprout a horn. But no—it’s teased, and then it just... isn’t. And that’s the pattern. Even the climax flirts with something strange and possibly cosmic. Spoiler: there's this shimmering, sci-fi dark matter moment—a ripple in reality that hints at consequences or transcendence. But it stays exactly that: a ripple. Not a wave. Not a flood. Not even a splash. It’s like watching someone stroke the surface of something unknowable... and then walk away. No payoff. No consequence. Just cinematic almost-there. You almost climax, but not quite. It’s this weird tension: it both overreaches and underdelivers. Instead of doubling down on its chaos, it backs into a corner and plays safe. And once that happens, the absurd doesn’t feel absurd anymore—it feels calculated. Tame. Which brings me to the ending. Let’s be honest: it’s Disney. Not classic Disney, but like, post-modern, irony-poisoned Disney. The unicorn family is reunited. Cue the swelling music. Cue the sentimental glaze. It’s “gore princess” energy, or better yet, “Disney horse girl but make it necro.” And honestly? If they were gonna lean that way, they should’ve galloped into it. Go full silhouette-against-the-sunset. Paul Rudd riding a unicorn with his daughter, straight-faced, into a glowing pink horizon. So dumb it loops back to genius. That ending would’ve committed. It would’ve earned the cliche by owning it. Instead, what we got felt... safe. Bland. Like they built an entire twisted mythos and then abandoned it at the altar of digestibility. And that’s why, despite how much I enjoyed the ride—and I did—I can’t help but feel that twinge of disappointment. This is a transitional movie. If there was a Unicorn film for a past generation, this is the one for the weird, ironic, late-millennial and Gen Z cohort. It’s for the horse girls who became sad women, for the kids who loved Lisa Frank and grew up into therapists and cynics. My niece is ten. She’d adore this film. And I mean that sincerely. This would be her Unicorn movie—the one she rewatches, quotes, turns into a sticker on her water bottle. And maybe one day, she’ll see it again as an adult and laugh at how it made her feel, while still kind of feeling it. So I land here: This movie earns a 90/100—not because it’s perfect, but because it had the capacity to be. And sometimes you give that grade not as a reward, but as a challenge. It’s still an A. But it’s not the A. And that's the paradox: I liked it. I really liked it. But it could’ve been mythic.

Death of a Unicorn fully embraces its bizarre premise with a wild, surreal, and at times comical detour from traditional cinema fare that’s never boring and heightened by its cast and bombastic absurdity!

Was it convoluted? Yes. Was it a wee bit ridiculous? Yes. Was it messy? Yes. Was it funny? Yes. Was it a wee bit heart stirring? Yes. Was it a fun horror? Yes. I found myself, several times, thinking, "What are you doing?" "Come on!" and "You've got to be kidding me!" And barely keeping it under my breath. Yes, we know (if you have some historical and scientific knowledge) that what was historically called a "unicorn" is what we call a rhinoceros, but I can go with the fantasy factor of this movie. They do miss the mark in the concept of pressing toward heaven, almost failing to have a gospel reference to anything in the film, but not appropriating it correctly anyway. Nevertheless, some visuals are absolutely beautiful, the scenery was breathtaking, the effects were mostly good, even if many were spoiled by the trailers. Overall, though, it was a decent movie. If predictable, it was still satisfying. Oh, yes, it is far better than the Snow White movie. Definitely see it. Might even be less terrifying in some respects.
The bond that Ridley and Elliot Kiltner would eventually share throughout the film was deeply moving.
It was good but not great. Needed more character development and maybe a little more to the story.
Great chemistry between Ortega and Rudd save this otherwise comically twisted cast of characters who are picked off one by one by the sensitive and powerful equines.

The acting overall was solid but Will Poulter's character was definitely the best. The story was mostly formulaic but still engaging with a good amount of dark humor that actually hit the mark. The special effects were good. There was a surprising amount of graphic gore but it didn't feel out of place.

Can’t believe I’m saying this, but I would rather watch opus than this sad, talentless disaster of a movie. There is not even a single character in this movie. I thought I was excited for Tia Leone since it’s been about 10 years, but she can just go back to whatever she was doing. Jesus, is A24 always been this insufferable? Like did you guys know that rich people can suck? <—-entire message of movie. One day I will be so drunk coming home and putting on streaming that I will see this and actively throw something at my TV and break it, and that will still be better than actually watching this again. I would pay triple the money to unsee this in fact. If this is this guy‘s first movie, he should just end his career now. Truly a pathetic mess of a movie.

Paul Rudd, Jenna Ortega, Tea Leoni, and Will Poulter Based on the book by Peter Dickinson When we think of unicorns we think majestic, kind, and all around pleasant This puts a whole new spin on the ultimate fantasy of us ignoring our mortality Ortega and Rudd play daughter and father, Ridley and Elliot The mother is deceased and the only hope they have is a new business venture with Leopold that will set them for life Leopold Labs is headed by Mr. Leopold himself since he’s facing an incurable disease Ridley and her dad accidentally run over a mythical creature…a unicorn of all things Arriving at the Leopold estate all of them are shocked to discover it; so they take it in for study and find out it has healing properties It’s blood can cure any ailment even cancer itself At first it’s a scientific/medical breakthrough but Ridley does her own research to find out that unicorns are not all they’re cracked up to be in ancient mythology as well as history It’s not just their lore the movie explores but also their emotional valence They’re actually more savage in nature and will make humanity pay the ultimate price abusing their biological properties Ridley also shares a connection with the deceased unicorn and the parents of this creature go on a killing rampage The movie is just alright, it should’ve been better though There are comments on upper class consciousness, socialism, capitalism, choosing immortality regardless of consequences, not sharing breakthroughs with the rest of the world, choosing monetary rewards over the bigger picture, symbolism for corruption, addiction, science deniers, looking at grief and loss, the pharmaceutical industry, and using mythical creatures as metaphors to deal with our transgressions Ok so maybe the satire is a bit heavy handed, most of the characters aren’t likable to completely sell it, the pacing is a big mawkish, it also feels like the filmmakers play things way too safe with a premise this crazy, and I wanted more outrageous ness when it came to the grisly kills I also didn’t laugh as much as I wanted too as I only got some minor chuckles Plus some of the effects needed some more time to look seamless A better screenplay would’ve helped make this standout but as disposable entertainment by A24 Studios there’s far worse
